texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: /2010/12/14/mounting-a-raw-partition-file-made-with-dd-or-dd_rescue-in-linux/
texts.text: /2010/12/14/mounting-a-raw-partition-file-made-with-dd-or-dd_rescue-in-linux/

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: command line
texts.text: command line

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: emergency
texts.text: emergency

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: sysadmin
texts.text: sysadmin

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This situation might not affect everyone, but it struck me today and left me scratching my head. Consider a situation where you need to clone one drive to another with  dd  or when a hard drive is failing badly and you use  dd_rescue  to salvage whatever data you can.
texts.text: This situation might not affect everyone, but it struck me today and left me scratching my head. Consider a situation where you need to clone one drive to another with  dd  or when a hard drive is failing badly and you use  dd_rescue  to salvage whatever data you can.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's say you cloned data from a drive using something like this:
texts.text: Let's say you cloned data from a drive using something like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: # dd if=/dev/sda of=/mnt/nfs/backup/harddrive.img
texts.text: # dd if=/dev/sda of=/mnt/nfs/backup/harddrive.img

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once that's finished, you should end up with your partition table as well as the grub data from the MBR in your image file. If you run
texts.text: Once that's finished, you should end up with your partition table as well as the grub data from the MBR in your image file. If you run

texts.label: code
texts.orig: file
texts.text: file

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: against the image file you made, you should see something like this:
texts.text: against the image file you made, you should see something like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# file harddrive.img
harddrive.img: x86 boot sector; GRand Unified Bootloader, stage1 version 0x3, stage2
address 0x2000, stage2 segment 0x200, GRUB version 0.97; partition 1: ID=0x83,
active, starthead 1, startsector 63, 33640047 sectors, code offset 0x48
texts.text:
# file harddrive.img
harddrive.img: x86 boot sector; GRand Unified Bootloader, stage1 version 0x3, stage2
address 0x2000, stage2 segment 0x200, GRUB version 0.97; partition 1: ID=0x83,
active, starthead 1, startsector 63, 33640047 sectors, code offset 0x48

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: What if you want to pull some files from this image without writing it out to another disk? Mounting it like a loop file isn't going to work:
texts.text: What if you want to pull some files from this image without writing it out to another disk? Mounting it like a loop file isn't going to work:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# mount harddrive /mnt/temp
mount: you must specify the filesystem type
texts.text:
# mount harddrive /mnt/temp
mount: you must specify the filesystem type

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The key is to mount the file  with an offset specified . In the output from
texts.text: The key is to mount the file  with an offset specified . In the output from

texts.label: code
texts.orig: file
texts.text: file

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , there is a particular portion of the output that will help you:
texts.text: , there is a particular portion of the output that will help you:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ... startsector 63 ...
texts.text: ... startsector 63 ...

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This means that the filesystem itself starts on sector 63. You can also view this with
texts.text: This means that the filesystem itself starts on sector 63. You can also view this with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: fdisk -l
texts.text: fdisk -l

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# fdisk -l harddrive.img
                    Device Boot      Start         End      Blocks   Id  System
harddrive.img                *          63    33640109    16820023+  83  Linux
texts.text:
# fdisk -l harddrive.img
                    Device Boot      Start         End      Blocks   Id  System
harddrive.img                *          63    33640109    16820023+  83  Linux

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Since we need to scoot 63 sectors ahead, and each sector is 512 bytes long, we need to use an offset of 32,256 bytes. Fire up the mount command and you'll be on your way:
texts.text: Since we need to scoot 63 sectors ahead, and each sector is 512 bytes long, we need to use an offset of 32,256 bytes. Fire up the mount command and you'll be on your way:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# mount -o ro,loop,offset=32256 harddrive.img /mnt/loop
# mount | grep harddrive.img
/root/harddrive.img on /mnt/loop type ext3 (ro,loop=/dev/loop1,offset=32256)
texts.text:
# mount -o ro,loop,offset=32256 harddrive.img /mnt/loop
# mount | grep harddrive.img
/root/harddrive.img on /mnt/loop type ext3 (ro,loop=/dev/loop1,offset=32256)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you made this image under duress (due to a failing drive or other emergency), you might have to check and repair the filesystem first. Doing that is easy if you make a loop device:
texts.text: If you made this image under duress (due to a failing drive or other emergency), you might have to check and repair the filesystem first. Doing that is easy if you make a loop device:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# losetup --offset 32256 /dev/loop2 harddrive.img
# fsck /dev/loop2
texts.text:
# losetup --offset 32256 /dev/loop2 harddrive.img
# fsck /dev/loop2

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once that's complete, you can save some time and mount the loop device directly:
texts.text: Once that's complete, you can save some time and mount the loop device directly:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: # mount /dev/loop2 /mnt/loop
texts.text: # mount /dev/loop2 /mnt/loop
